page.title: 12Physical Geog. Of Coalville
page.content: Coalville is sited on a gently undulating plateau approx. 525' above sea level, part of the North-West Leic. Coalfield. The site slopes south and south-westwards to the valley of the River Sence and its tributaries. The R.Sence flows east to west immediately to the south of{Coalville and is joined near Kelham Bridge by a tributary flowing southwards from Snibston. These two streams then flow south-westwards into the catchment area of the R.Tame, and ultimately in- to the R.Trent. To the east and south- east of Coalville the land rises gently, reaching its highest point at {Bardon Hill}(912ft). The local rocks consist of Triassic rocks-sands, clays etc., underlain by the coal measures, which incline towards the older rocks of the Charnwood Forest which lies to the north and north-east.
